newsitem.title: UK: Sugar demand seen rising in Indian Ocean nations.
newsitem.headline: Sugar demand seen rising in Indian Ocean nations.

text.p: The 14 cane producing nations of the Indian Ocean Rim (IOR) could boost world sugar demand by up to seven million tonnes if their economies developed more, the former South Africa Sugar Association chairman said on Tuesday.

In an opening speech at a two-day seminar hosted by the International Sugar Organization (ISO), John Chance said the IOR's per capita sugar consumption could be estimated at 16 kg, four kg lower than the world average.

"There should be an increase in the per capita consumption of sugar and bridging that gap up to the world average would see a significant improvement in consumption of some six or seven million tonnes of sugar," Chance said.
"These are significant numbers for sugar producers."

The IOR turned out 26 million tonnes of sugar annually, representing 22 percent of world production. At around 21.5 million tonnes, the IOR's sugar consumption accounted for 19 percent of the global figure, he said.
One of the problems facing the IOR group, he said, was that many of the commodities produced in the relatively poor countries were based on agriculture and were of low raw value.
"Until all countries in the region add value to their raw materials and produce more manufactured goods, the region cannot hope to develop as any sort of player on the world scene," Chance said.
